awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Accelerated simulation of nonlinear solids with applications to human anatomy modeling in interactive virtual environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Digital models of human anatomy, already common elements of motion pictures and computer games, are now increasingly being incorporated into diverse "serious" applications such as medical diagnostics, surgical planning and vehicle design.  Both current and emerging applications demand improved photorealism, enhanced biomechanical accuracy, better subject specificity and faster simulation algorithms.  As these demands often outpace the evolution of computer hardware, new algorithms for biomechanical modeling and simulation are necessary to ensure that upcoming computational platforms are utilized to the best of their capacity.

With respect to computational performance, physics-based simulations of virtual materials in interactive applications have demonstrated inferior performance in terms of cost per degree of freedom when compared to large-scale simulations of similar phenomena in HPC settings.  This is partly attributable to the regularity and economy of scale associated with large models, compared to the pronounced irregularity and heterogeneity at lower resolutions.  But it is also due to the fact that the commonly-used algorithms and data structures for interactive virtual materials reflect design compromises with respect to features, accuracy and parallelization potential.  In this project the PI will endeavor to show that it is possible to reinvent both algorithms and data structures so as to achieve optimal computational efficiency for nonlinear virtual materials even under the constraints of interactive simulation, and also to achieve improvements of orders of magnitude in runtime, resolution and accuracy.  The work will leverage expertise from computer systems, scientific computing, continuum mechanics and numerical analysis.

Biomechanical simulation has provided a great opportunity for transformative advances in medical practice using virtual models of the human body for disease prevention and treatment.  These emerging applications mandate an increased level of attention to the unique demands of interactivity, resolution and anatomical accuracy for clinical uses of biomechanical modeling and simulation.  Algorithmic improvements that yield two or three orders of magnitude have the potential to transform clinical training or operation planning tasks from off-line processes to practical interactive experiences.  In addition to being a valuable opportunity to improve patient care, the use of anatomical modeling as a testing ground for effective and scalable simulation algorithms will have a lasting legacy that extends well beyond the clinical field.  The high degree of irregularity in shape and function that is inherent in human tissues yields an excellent and challenging benchmark for the validity of material models, the accuracy of discretization techniques and the efficiency of numerical solvers.  Considerations such as the accommodation of topology change and facilitation of parallel processing make simulating virtual nonlinear tissue models an excellent opportunity to refine core computational physics and numerical analysis techniques.

Broader Impacts:  Computer simulations have been established as an educational tool in many fields (e.g., driving and flight training), helping to improve the safety record of operators without risk of physical harm.  They present a great opportunity to affect the quality of patient care, considering the fact that most surgical residents currently sharpen their skills while operating on actual patients.  Anatomical simulators could also reduce the need for animal testing, and help with knowledge transfer across the international clinical community, especially in developing countries.  As part of this project, the PI will develop new academic course offerings that will serve to connect computer engineers, applied mathematicians, and clinical practitioners.

por.por_cntn:
Computer modeling has afforded us the opportunity to recreate digital replicas of elements of our natural environment that look and function like their physical counterparts. Digital humans and computer-generated creatures, for example, are ubiquitous in motion pictures, while also becoming common visual elements in virtual environments that help train medical practitioners in planning procedures or responding to emergencies. Similarly, computer-aided simulation of the mechanical function of devices, tools and vehicles has become an indispensable prototyping tool in industrial design and engineering, allowing the performance of such products to be tested and tuned on a computer, without being physically manufactured. The practical success of such computer-modeling techniques, largely catalyzed by advances in computer hardware, has fueled an insatiable urge for higher detail, larger scale, and enhanced fidelity. Achieving this goal, however, is not a straightforward engineering exercise: the pursuit of accurately capturing diverse functional behaviors in simulated objects is often a hindrance in creating the necessary preconditions for optimal utilization of modern parallel computing platforms, which are absolutely essential for enhancing scale and detail of simulations. 

 

This project drew its core motivation from the accepted reality that the dramatically increased computational capabilities that modern parallel hardware offers us come at the expense of idiosyncrasies of the underlying platform and complexities of the programming model (relative to simpler, non-parallel computers of decades past) that need to be respected for optimal performance. These traits require an increased level of awareness about the computational platform and its architecture when designing simulation algorithms and their associated data structures. In addition, they highlight the need for engaging in coordinated, cross-layer interventions across many of the contributing areas of expertise that computer simulation relies on, to enable transformative innovations: the mathematical formulations that derive discrete equations from continuous governing laws, the data structures used for their representation, accelerated numerical algorithms used to solve compartmentalized problems, and the methodology by which parallelization is facilitated often need to be jointly considered in a coordinated design process.

 

This research has chosen the modeling and simulation of human anatomy models as the core proving ground of such innovations, and there was a significant reason for this: High-efficiency parallel computing is predicated, among others, on the significant regularity of the computation to be performed; modern computers can concurrently accommodate a vast number of computational tasks, if those tasks are as similar as possible. The nature of human soft tissue, and the intricacies of the applications that such models are used in, however, present profound challenges to regularity and efficient parallel computation, and this project tackled such challenges in multiple fronts: New methods were introduced to recover regularity of computation in materials that have significant diversity of composition, and substantial irregularity of shape, by using regular data structures as a "scaffolding" within which the variation in shape and composition can be better controlled. Techniques were proposed to reconcile the frequent topological changes - cutting and suturing - that surgical simulations require, along with the complex collision problems that arise in this context with the regularity and uniformity computation patterns that parallel processing demands. Finally, we addressed the needs of control problems, where the functional parameters of an anatomical model (e.g. the contractile activation patterns of individual muscles) had to be inferred from a desired high-level function, rather than being prescribed as input.

 

A flagship product of our efforts has been an interactive training simulator for reconstructive plastic surgery procedures on the human scalp, which has been used in pilot workshops attended by medical residents at the University of Wisconsin. Our findings were archived in top-tier publications both in the Computer Graphics and Plastic Surgery communities. 

 

This project's products had a utility that transcended the specific, human anatomy-focused application that motivated it. An exemplar of the innovations possible with a hardware-conscious design of data structures and algorithms has been SPGrid, a data structure for storage of sparse, grid-embedded data that was intimately reliant on the intricacies of the virtual memory system in modern processors to deliver performance and scalability. A mathematical framework was developed for solving large-scale sparse systems of equations on heterogeneous large-memory servers equipped by several GPUs, and demonstrated in part in highly detailed simulations of air flow in the human respiratory system. Our newly introduced methodologies also extended to simulation of highly-detailed fluid flows, and complex materials (elastoplastic media, particle-laden fluids, etc) using the Material Point Method with hardware-conscious algorithmic components.
